segments.text: You've received more cooperation in terms of large missions, joint cooperations, oceanographic institutions, international cooperation in terms of working the deep seas.
I suppose so.
I think now it's possible for people to travel.

world's become smaller and we also have a closer personal relationship with foreign scientists so we but we can do this in a more meaningful and workable way before it was mainly a matter of sort of hands across the seamanship of meeting people from foreign countries and doing good things and but now i think it'll become more more meaningful and getting just the people you want i mean it'll be based more upon their scientific
capability in which you're going to get out of it rather than just being more or less a social thing, social phenomenon.
So I think the...
In other words, we will find talent wherever it is regardless of nationality.
And people that have common interests or have compatible interests will work together and cooperate in a much more
productive and meaningful way.
So I think there'll be more cooperation.
I would hope that there's a tendency, of course, to establish very large projects.
And this is typical in the meteorology field where you have had a series of major expeditions which involve tens of millions of dollars of input and Bomex and

various things and these are these are extremely expensive and I guess it's one way of kind of organizing in a way where you can get some funding on this level because you by having a large project you can go to the top so to speak and and get you get support but myself I personally not I don't like to be involved in these things because you're

You spend so much time in the mechanics of organizing committee meetings and organizing things, and I'm afraid the, for example, the IPOD, the International Phase of Ocean Drilling, deep sea drilling project has been a great success, but of course very expensive.
The Mohul project became defunct.
And thank God it did.
I mean, this was totally out of hand.
The conceptually wrong became a political project.
There was a contract given to the wrong company and so forth and so on.
So when it died, it had a few friends left in the scientific community.
And it was being more or less kept afloat only by a few political interests.
But then we
this fell apart and we regrouped as a deep-sea drilling project, which was fine.
It was really what was suggested in the first place by such people as Miliani that we should take sediment cars.
But now this is the iPod and as an outsider looking at it, it's become enormously complex because it's
The number of committees and subcommittees and world traveling involved in the organization is becoming highly, highly complex.
But I suppose that in the long run, the results will become more meaningful, too.
It's very difficult.
Well, you can get money for expeditions and for big projects, but it's very difficult to get funding to work up the results.
And this always has been this way, I guess it always will be.
I hope they become more sophisticated and can learn that or somehow organize things to make sure the results do in fact get published.
It has also been suggested now that the emphasis is on the ocean as being a productive unit, that more and more it'll be difficult to work in the deep water.
And more and more oceanographers will concentrate upon things like the Gulf Shelf.
Would you agree with that?
Well, this is true now.
It may be a passing phase.
I mean, these are things which hopefully a man can solve.
And this will be a great difficulty for the next decade.
I see that in the 1980s that this matter of legal boundaries and working
having nations controlling the seas after 200 miles, this divides the ocean up into a great many private domains and this becomes very ponderable and people go shy away from it.
I worked off Africa as a chief scientist on one of our ships and we had to get these permissions.
These permissions
eventually came through, but nearly always too late.
We already had left the area.
And it raised havoc with all of our programs to try to do something in terms of reference of these.
I mean, we had to, for example, we had to program our ship to be in Dakar.
And because there was an election going on, and on a certain day, we had to be
we were imposed upon by our own State Department to be out of Dakar, I don't know, five days before the election and not back in until two days after.
Otherwise, it would appear there was some sort of show of U.S. force on the elections that we were showing the flag.
So we had to, anyway, this is maybe one thing like that you can live with.
But suppose you have a dozen to live with and you have an operation on the African coast
and you try to arrange your plans to fit into all these requirements, it becomes just totally impossible to operate.
Do you feel there's been a proliferation of universities offering degrees in oceanography?
Yes, I think probably too many.
I read recently here that there are
10,000 unemployed divers, and I'm sure this is an underestimate.

And the Florida Institute of Technology is hoping to improve this by developing a course in superdivers, whereby diving is just sort of an adjunct to something they can do as a technician, which is the way it should be.
But oceanographers are being probably overproduced.

There's been no... Oceanography has been entirely a sort of government-supported activity, unless we enlarge the definition of oceanography to include fishing and merchant marine and such things as that.
So it's become a very large science and probably out of proportion to the employment in the field.
So it's very difficult, I think, for...
oceanographers to my unemployment.
And, well, it was very difficult when I began, too.
And this is because there were none.
There was no precedent.
Come in.
I rather suspect that when...
When I first began, I got my degree as a Ph.D. in geology, marine geology.
Just before the war, Ken Emery, who was much more aggressive or energetic than I am, he wrote 146 letters looking for a position.
And he was a Phi Beta Kappa, and he had all sorts of top credentials.
He didn't get one favorable reply.
I sat back while he wrote his letters and encouraged him.
And I thought he'd get two replies, and I'd be like Avis.
I would try to be second best, you see, and pick up something he didn't take.
All I corresponded to, he got no replies.
Of course, there was no sort of counseling service to act for you.
No one knew what an oceanographer was, a marine geologist was.
All companies didn't recognize the sub-discipline.
Well, it almost seems, if an outsider looks in upon your profession, that immediately after the war, that ONR and the National Science Foundation
sit out to encourage the development of oceanography departments.
They'd say, we need to have somebody in chemical oceanography, let's say, and there's not anything really organized.
Let's see if we can build a department at X university to do such.
Is that the way you perceive the broadening of the field of oceanography academically?
Yes, it was well organized from within whereby it was an attempt by NSF and ONR and other groups to

Establish the Sea Grant schools, which was, of course, Spillhouse was instrumental in, and so But also there was a great interest on a part of the populace and universities to in fact do it because it is a very exciting field and We did have people like Cousteau and do have him around which have given a very glossy view
of oceanography.
Most oceanographers are critical of Cousteau, and I suppose I am too, although he's a very good friend of mine, and I've sailed in a ship and admire him.
He's been a great spokesman for oceanography, and I really admire what he's done.
But at the same time, people do misinterpret what his role is.
It's like
It's like thinking Ronald Reagan is a president rather than a movie actor or something like that.
You have to recognize that.
And so, and there's been a great many people just come to you all the time in droves and say, well, my son likes to die.
He wants to become an ocean armor permit.
And this, of course, is like saying, I know how to type.
I want to become a historian.
Yeah, right.
Would you suggest, if one wanted to become an oceanographer, that he be trained as an undergraduate in a hard science rather than a general degree in oceanography?
In general, yes.
And I think there's room for both programs.
And Texas A&M and FIT and University of Washington, of course, have this undergraduate program.
So I think there's room for all approaches.

I think that we need more ocean technicians, perhaps, and if you take a hard science, I think you're more or less preparing, and you go towards a PhD program, you're more or less preparing yourself for a career as a research scientist.

this this uh this field of creating research science is probably is overpopulated i mean there's too much emphasis upon the upon the the phd upon academic science and not enough upon other approaches to but i i in spite of the fact where i say that we may be over producing oceanographers
Let's face it, we're overproducing maybe historians and psychology majors in even greater numbers, aren't we?
So if we're overproducing in a field, I think it should be in a field of technology, of science.
I think these people do become...
useful citizens and useful and employable people.
Even though they may not end up in their chosen field, I think they become highly employable people.
And so these people that are trained in oceanography are not pumping gas.
They're employable people and they're doing things.
I don't know what they're doing.
I don't know where they all go.
But they do end up having useful careers in general.
I realize that no one has any luck on predicting the future.
However, let me offer you perhaps a chance to.

It seems as if about the time that you enter the field of oceanography, that may I say the hot fields in oceanography are really marine geology and then works with charting and mapping, particularly moving towards charting and mapping in the deep oceans.
physical oceanography.
Then, with the explosion of the bomb, then the hot field tends to be physics and physics and oceanography.
What would you suggest in what direction the future in oceanography will be?
Well, the explosion of the bomb, there was a great proliferation of nuclear physicists, and these were the
There's remarkable prestige associated with being a nuclear physicist to the point that they even got... Any nuclear physicist was a great man regardless of what he did.
And even if he was a poor one, he could be the head of an oceanographic laboratory by his prestige.
But...
In oceanography, the future...
Well, the greatest success in oceanography, I think, has been the concept of plate tectonics.
If you look at a new textbook in geology, I taught geology at Washington last semester,
There only are two new chapters in classical geology.
One concerns planetology, the planets.
The other really concerns plate tectonics, the new model of the world.
These are the two new things.
And of course, plate tectonics is mainly based upon the data of marine geology and geophysics.
It's a triumph, really, for understanding the ocean floor.
And the whole field of plate tectonics is likely to be a very bright field.
for many years.
I mean, for several decades we will be making very useful results in understanding earthquake prediction and mechanics of the Earth's surface and interpreting these in terms of mineral deposits.
So, I think there's a, while the frontier may not be quite endless, there is still a great frontier and

in the oceans and it is deep oceans are 60% of the earth and so there's an enormous amount of work to be done in marine geology and I think there will be very exciting discoveries and it's a very very promising field I think that the
Earlier, we were talking about large projects, one of these large projects, which is, you know, like the International Oceanographic Expedition was based upon, really, it's a geographic thing.
There are other large projects which are ongoing and which are based on problem solving.
Now, the CLIMAP program, understanding more about past climates in terms of
bringing together people who can do this thing all over the world, both on land and in the sea, looking at deep sea sediments.
This is a very fine project.
And I'm sure that there'll be some great results coming from Climap.
And a good part of this input will be marine geologic.
But we'll learn more to understand more about how the Earth really works, not only the
the crust but also the ocean itself.
I don't think even today we know what would happen if we dammed the Straits of Gibraltar.
We know that there's a water mass coming out of there which is warm and saline and becomes mid-water, North Atlantic mid-water and can be observed up off Ireland.
And this is a very important
oceanic phenomenon.
But how it affects climates, nobody knows.
You could build a scenario saying it would cause the earth to get colder by blocking the straits, or you can make a scenario equally rational saying the world might get warmer, you see.
So we don't really know the effects of oceanography
on the scale where we can really understand the ocean of the world.
This is something which will be forthcoming.
What happens when we block the Bering Sea or something like the Bering Straits?
What would happen if we have a sea level canal going through Panama?
Now the other thing which is developed in oceanography, which is very important, is satellite oceanography.
Because we'll have a sea satellite, SeaSat-1, I guess be launched in a couple of years from now.
And we'll be able to, for the first time, to get a synoptic view of the ocean, know what's going on.
I guess every 18 days we'd occupy the same station.
And so the state of the sea can be assessed, the roughness and warmth and so forth.
And so this whole idea of remote sensing of the ocean is a new and bright field.
And I guess to process the data involved in Seasat will take an enormous group of people to process that data.
And of course, when you do have a synoptic view of the

ocean it'll in turn give us some sort of a long-term view of climate and it'll be enormously profitable too because if we can predict climate or predict these things seem to be rather small problems but they have enormous consequence i mean in terms of their economic
spinoff involved in understanding the climate just a little bit more will make oceanography probably an economic thing to really understand more about the world.
So things like this, I think, have a very bright future.
Remote sensing, plate tectonics of the ocean floor,
learning more about the total, the picture of the ocean, the climate project and things of that are very useful and very important programs.
Now in terms of oceanographic training or training for oceanographers then,
Would you suggest that oceanographers will spend more time at sea or less time at sea?
Will they spend more time trying to sort through the data they already have in terms of now the new impact of the computer, or will there be more sea voyages?
Well, I...
I guess it would be more steady state.
You wouldn't really, you can see more reason to, certainly with satellites, you can, this will be at the need for some surface observations.
And with remote sensing from aircraft and use of submarines and DRVs, deep submersibles, these,
Oceanography may be done in a different way.

Now, of course, the primary vehicle of oceanography is the surface ship, and it probably will remain so, but it'll be supplemented to a much more important degree by satellite oceanography and other techniques of data gathering.
The science is only as good as instrumentation
But once you develop a new instrument, it really opens up enormous possibilities.
For example, the advent of echo sounding.
And we get to the point where we really think we can see the ocean floor.
We see mountains in our minds and so forth.
Of course, we've never seen it.
That's all.
But in our minds, we think we see the ocean floor.
But the other thing which has been an enormous development has been the reflection profile whereby we get sort of an x-ray radiographic vision of the sediments, their thickness on the ocean floor.
And once we improve this technique, its resolution,
Or once we get more powerful tools whereby we can, say, bounce echoes off the moho, this justifies a whole new survey of the ocean for this purpose alone.
And so the more we know about problems, the more problems that we really generate.
And I guess in a very social way, also, we
People have to keep busy.
They have to keep employed, you know.
They have to have.
And so we're not going to get to the point where we just sit around and sit on our data doing anything.
We're always going to be looking for new problems to solve.
And some of these problems, even if they're non-problems, we're going to try to solve them.
I wondered perhaps if maybe this romantic attraction to the sea that took people like you and Emory and Shepard to the sea, if this may...
maybe through for oceanographers, maybe if they should work more with satellites or what have you, maybe the day-by-day getting your foot wet, as Ravel said, may be gone.
Well, perhaps so.
I think there's something to this, but it may also be aging on the part of Ravel and myself and other people.
I think young people are bound to be romantic, and they're bound to have this.
Certainly people that...
in the scuba diving community, for example.
They're highly caught up with the romance of the sea.
And we don't see any let up in people being interested in sailing and boating.
Of course, when we first worked off California, we worked in sort of frontiers.
We were going out and just going along the long California coast or out to the islands.
These were sort of unknown territories then, which few people had visited.
And now, of course, they're highly populated.
The whole thing has changed.
So I think that people like Ravel and some of the early people, they did things of the missionary zeal.
They weren't in it as more or less as a way of making a living.
They were in it just for the romance of the sea.
The sea was very mysterious then.
It's less so now because we know more about it.
And I guess as we begin to understand the world better, people still look for mysticism.
I mean, more than half the world believes in UFOs.
Some 80% of the people believe in horoscopes or something like that.
They believe in the effect of
of stars have upon their birth, although one would think that the moment they were conceived would be more important than when they're actually born, more or less like their Chinese birthday.
You see, when you're in China, when you're born, you're a year old on whatever their New Year's is.
And if you're born the day after their New Year's, which is something like February 20th, you're two years old.
You're another year old.
So you can be two days old, and you can be two years old.
And the gravitational effect of Jupiter on me is no greater than the effect of you sitting there on me.
And the gravitational effect of you is larger.
But people persist in looking for mysticism in the world, and always will.
And there's a need for it, I suppose.
And the more we open up a rational world, the more people will seek out mysticism.
And so you think the romance of the sea will continue to attract young people into oceanography?
I think it will, yes.
The romance of the sea will continue to.
And it remains fascinating, it really does, particularly all aspects of the sea.
The life in the sea is much more diverse than life on land, the invertebrates and the types of animals there.
So, and to me, it still is a very
remarkable environment.
And so I think the romance of the sea will certainly remain.
